message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Agent Hospital: A Simulacrum of Hospital with Evolvable Medical Agents
Paper Abstract: The recent rapid development of large language models (LLMs) has sparked a new wave of technological revolution in medical artificial intelligence (AI). While LLMs are designed to understand and generate text like a human, autonomous agents that utilize LLMs as their "brain" have exhibited capabilities beyond text processing such as planning, reflection, and using tools by enabling their "bodies" to interact with the environment. We introduce a simulacrum of hospital called Agent Hospital that simulates the entire process of treating illness, in which all patients, nurses, and doctors are LLM-powered autonomous agents. Within the simulacrum, doctor agents are able to evolve by treating a large number of patient agents without the need to label training data manually. After treating tens of thousands of patient agents in the simulacrum (human doctors may take several years in the real world), the evolved doctor agents outperform state-of-the-art medical agent methods on the MedQA benchmark comprising US Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) test questions. Our methods of simulacrum construction and agent evolution have the potential in benefiting a broad range of applications beyond medical AI.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Automated Planning - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about automated planning. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

### Core Problem

The planning problem is to synthesize a plan given a description of possible initial states, desired goals, and possible actions, which is guaranteed to generate a state containing the desired goals.

### Key Approaches

Several different planning methodologies exist:

1. **Partial-Order Planning**: Partial-order planning is an approach to automated planning that maintains a partial ordering between actions and only commits ordering between actions when forced to.

2. **Reactive Planning**: Reactive planning denotes a group of techniques for action selection by autonomous agents that operate in a timely fashion and hence can cope with highly dynamic and unpredictable environments.

3. **Satisfiability-Based Planning**: Satplan (Planning as Satisfiability) is a method for automated planning that converts the planning problem instance into an instance of the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT), which is then solved using a method for establishing satisfiability.

### Standardization

The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence planning languages, first developed by Drew McDermott and colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the International Planning Competition possible.

Web search results for query: "Reinforcement learning reward shaping"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reward hacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_hacking"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Reward system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"}]

I found relevant information about reward shaping in reinforcement learning. Here's what the search results show:

## Reward Shaping

Reward shaping is a technique that gives an agent intermediate rewards that are customized to fit the agent's learning. It's used as a method to aid agents in exploration during reinforcement learning tasks.

The search results indicate that the idea behind curiosity-driven exploration is to give the agent motivation to explore unknown outcomes, which is done by modifying the loss function or network architecture by adding terms to incentivize exploration.

However, the search results also highlight an important challenge: reward hacking or specification gaming occurs when an AI trained with reinforcement learning optimizes an objective function—achieving the literal, formal specification of an objective—without actually achieving an outcome that the programmers intended. This is a critical consideration when designing reward functions in RL systems.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Text Generation:

## Natural Language Processing

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.(no content)Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.

## Natural Language Generation

Natural language generation (NLG) is a software process that produces natural language output. More specifically, NLG is described as "the subfield of artificial intelligence and computational linguistics that is concerned with the construction of computer systems that can produce understandable texts in English or other human languages from some underlying non-linguistic representation of information".(no content)Common applications of NLG methods include the production of various reports, for example weather and patient reports; image captions; and chatbots like ChatGPT.

## Modern Approaches: Large Language Models

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)Major tools include LLM-based chatbots such as ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, DeepSeek, Google Gemini and Grok; text-to-image models such as Stable Diffusion, Midjourney, and DALL-E; and text-to-video models such as Veo and Sora.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence in healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_healthcare"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in mental health - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_mental_health"},{"title":"Diagnosis (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diagnosis_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Mycin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mycin"},{"title":"Rainier Mallol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Mallol"},{"title":"Michael F. Chiang - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_F._Chiang"},{"title":"Wu Jiandong - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wu_Jiandong"},{"title":"ITU-WHO Focus Group on Artificial Intelligence for Health - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITU-WHO_Focus_Group_on_Artificial_Intelligence_for_Health"},{"title":"University of Petra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Petra"}]

## Medical Artificial Intelligence

Based on the search results, here's an overview of medical artificial intelligence:

### Definition and Purpose

Artificial intelligence in healthcare is the application of artificial intelligence (AI) to analyze and understand complex medical and healthcare data.(no content)In some cases, it can exceed or augment human capabilities by providing better or faster ways to diagnose, treat, or prevent disease.

### Key Applications

Medical AI has diverse applications across healthcare:

- **Diagnosis and Classification**: AI in healthcare is often used for classification, to evaluate a CT scan or electrocardiogram or to identify high-risk patients for population health.

- **Electronic Health Records**: Through the use of machine learning, artificial intelligence can be able to substantially aid doctors in patient diagnosis through the analysis of mass electronic health records (EHRs).

- **Cancer Treatment**: Microsoft's AI project Hanover helps doctors choose cancer treatments from among the more than 800 medicines and vaccines. Its goal is to memorize all the relevant papers to predict which (combinations of) drugs will be most effective for each patient.

- **Cardiac Care**: A research in 2019 found that AI can be used to predict heart attack with up to 90% accuracy.

- **Mental Health**: Applications of AI in this field include the identification and diagnosis of mental disorders, analysis of electronic health records, development of personalized treatment plans, and analytics for suicide prevention.

### Remote Patient Monitoring

AI can assist in caring for patients remotely by monitoring their information through sensors. A wearable device may allow for constant monitoring of a patient and the ability to notice changes that may be less distinguishable by humans.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AutoGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto-GPT"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about autonomous agents in artificial intelligence:

## Definition and Core Concepts

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Characteristics and Capabilities

Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight, and they possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.(no content)Key characteristics include persistence, autonomy, social ability, and reactivity—agents have capabilities of task selection, prioritization, goal-directed behavior, and decision-making without human intervention.

## Modern Applications and Examples

Based on the search results, here's what I found about large language models:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Limitations

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and a[truncated in original]. However, these models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs). Additionally, open-weight LLMs have increasingly shaped the field since 2023, contributing to broader participation in AI development and greater transparency in model evaluation.

I found comprehensive information on text generation neural networks. Here's what the search results reveal:

## Overview

Text generation is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text and other forms of data.(no content)Natural language generation (NLG) is a software process that produces natural language output.

## Approaches to Text Generation

NLG techniques range from simple template-based systems like a mail merge that generates form letters, to systems that have a complex understanding of human grammar, and can also beaccomplished by training a statistical model using machine learning, typically on a large corpus of human-written texts.

## Key Neural Network Architectures

**Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs):** Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)LSTM (1995) was a breakthrough RNN which used various innovations to overcome the vanishing gradient problem, allowing efficient learning of long-sequence modelling.

**Transformers:** The transformer architecture, introduced in 2017, replaced recurrence with self-attention, allowing efficient parallelization, longer context handling, and scalable training on unprecedented data volumes.(no content)Starting in 2018, the OpenAI GPT series of decoder-only transformers became state of the art in natural language generation.

**Large Language Models:** Large language models (LLM) are trained on tokenized text from text corpora, and such systems include ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, LLaMA, and BLOOM. LLMs are capable of natural language processing, machine translation, and natural language generation.

I found comprehensive information on text generation neural networks. Here's what the search results reveal:

## Overview

Text generation is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text and other forms of data.(no content)Natural language generation (NLG) is a software process that produces natural language output.

## Approaches to Text Generation

NLG techniques range from simple template-based systems like a mail merge that generates form letters, to systems that have a complex understanding of human grammar, and can also beaccomplished by training a statistical model using machine learning, typically on a large corpus of human-written texts.

## Key Neural Network Architectures

**Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs):** Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)LSTM (1995) was a breakthrough RNN which used various innovations to overcome the vanishing gradient problem, allowing efficient learning of long-sequence modelling.

**Transformers:** The transformer architecture, introduced in 2017, replaced recurrence with self-attention, allowing efficient parallelization, longer context handling, and scalable training on unprecedented data volumes.(no content)Starting in 2018, the OpenAI GPT series of decoder-only transformers became state of the art in natural language generation.

**Large Language Models:** Large language models (LLM) are trained on tokenized text from text corpora, and such systems include ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, LLaMA, and BLOOM. LLMs are capable of natural language processing, machine translation, and natural language generation.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Synthetic intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_intelligence"},{"title":"Chinese room - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_room"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_System"},{"title":"SimScale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SimScale"},{"title":"Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_hypothesis"},{"title":"RARS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RARS"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Human-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of "simulation artificial intelligence":

## Key Concepts

**Artificial Intelligence**: AI is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making. It is a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and use learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

**Simulation in AI**: The general problem of simulating (or creating) intelligence has been broken into subproblems consisting of particular traits or capabilities that researchers expect an intelligent system to display.

## Whole Brain Simulation

One significant application is whole brain simulation. With whole brain simulation, a brain model is built by scanning and mapping a biological brain in detail, and then copying and simulating it on a computer system. The simulation model must be sufficiently faithful to the original, so that it behaves in practically the same way as the original brain.

## Practical Applications

Training an AI in a real-world driving environment is impractical, and is achieved through simulator-based testing. Additionally, simulators are designed to enable pre-programmed AI drivers to race against one another.

The search results show that simulation is a fundamental aspect of AI research, development, and training across various domains.

I've completed a web search for "tool use artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Overview
Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making. It is a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and use learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

## AI Tools and Applications
Current AI tools include LLM-based chatbots such as ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, DeepSeek, Google Gemini and Grok; text-to-image models such as Stable Diffusion, Midjourney, and DALL-E; and text-to-video models such as Veo and Sora.(no content)High-profile applications of AI include advanced web search engines (e.g., Google Search); recommendation systems (used by YouTube, Amazon, and Netflix); virtual assistants (e.g., Google Assistant, Siri, and Alexa); autonomous vehicles (e.g., Waymo); generative and creative tools (e.g., language models and AI art); and superhuman play and analysis in strategy games (e.g., chess and Go).

## AI-Assisted Software Development
AI-assisted software development is the use of artificial intelligence agents to augment the software development life cycle. It uses large language models (LLMs), natural language processing, and other AI technologies to assist software developers in a range of tasks from initial code generation to subsequent debugging, testing and documentation.

## Intelligent Automation
Intelligent automation (IA), or intelligent process automation, is a software term that refers to a combination of artificial intelligence (AI) and robotic process automation (RPA). Companies use intelligent automation to cut costs and streamline tasks by using artificial-intelligence-powered robotic software to mitigate repetitive tasks.

Web search results for query: "reflection learning agents"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Reflection (artificial intelligence)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Reflective learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflective_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_agent"},{"title":"Reflective practice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflective_practice"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Meta-learning (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta-learning_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Action learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_learning"},{"title":"Reflective listening - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflective_listening"}]

Here are the search results for "reflection learning agents":

The search results cover several related concepts:

## AI Agents and Reflection

In AI systems like large language models, reflection is an internal process of "thinking" about the steps leading to an answer, designed to be analogous to human metacognition or "thinking about thinking". It helps AI systems approach tasks that require multi-step reasoning, planning, and logical thought.(no content)In LLMs, special tokens can mark the beginning and end of reflection before producing a final response (e.g., <thinking>).

## Test-Time Compute

Reflection is a form of "test-time compute", where additional computational resources are used during inference.(no content)Increasing the length of the Chain-of-Thought reasoning process, by passing the output of the model back to its input and doing multiple network passes, increases inference-time scaling.

## Reinforcement Learning Applications

Reinforcement learning frameworks have also been used to steer the Chain-of-Thought.(no content)This has been used by Google DeepMind in a technique called Self-Correction via Reinforcement Learning (SCoRe) which rewards the model for improving its responses.

## Human Reflective Learning

The results also cover reflective learning in human education, where reflective learning is a form of education in which the student reflects upon their learning experiences, described as an intentional and complex process that recognizes the role of social context and experience, with the goals of clarifying and creating meaning in terms of self.

It helps AI systems approach tasks that require multi-step reasoning, planning, and logical thought.(no content)In LLMs, special tokens can mark the beginning and end of reflection before producing a final response (e.g., <thinking>).

## Test-Time Compute

Reflection is a form of "test-time compute", where additional computational resources are used during inference.(no content)Increasing the length of the Chain-of-Thought reasoning process, by passing the output of the model back to its input and doing multiple network passes, increases inference-time scaling.

## Reinforcement Learning Applications

Reinforcement learning frameworks have also been used to steer the Chain-of-Thought.(no content)This has been used by Google DeepMind in a technique called Self-Correction via Reinforcement Learning (SCoRe) which rewards the model for improving its responses.

## Human Reflective Learning

The results also cover reflective learning in human education, where reflective learning is a form of education in which the student reflects upon their learning experiences, described as an intentional and complex process that recognizes the role of social context and experience, with the goals of clarifying and creating meaning in terms of self.

Web search results for query: "agent evolution machine learning"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Evolutionary algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_algorithm"},{"title":"Genetic algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_algorithm"},{"title":"Learnable evolution model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learnable_evolution_model"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Neuroevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroevolution"},{"title":"History of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Evolutionary programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_programming"}]

I've completed the web search for "agent evolution machine learning". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Key Concepts

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Evolution of Agents

Evolutionary computing can evolve intelligent agents that appear to act in ways intended to maximize a "fitness function" influencing how many descendants each agent is allowed to leave.(no content)In evolutionary systems, a "fitness function" determines which agents are more likely to reproduce, which is analogous to natural selection, where organisms evolve to maximize their chances of survival and reproduction.

## Neuroevolution

Neuroevolution is a form of artificial intelligence that uses evolutionary algorithms to generate artificial neural networks, parameters, and rules, most commonly applied in artificial life, general game playing and evolutionary robotics.

## Learnable Evolution Model

The learnable evolution model (LEM) is a non-Darwinian methodology for evolutionary computation that employs machine learning to guide the generation of new individuals (candidate problem solutions).

## Integration with Other Methods

In machine learning, genetic algorithms were used in the 1980s and 1990s, and conversely, machine learning techniques have been used to improve the performance of genetic and evolutionary algorithms.

The search results show strong connections between agent-based systems, evolutionary computation, and machine learning, with various hybrid approaches combining these fields to create more effective intelligent systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Agent Hospital" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - The paper proposes a novel Agent Hospital simulacrum framework with evolvable medical agents.

**Key Entities Identified** (10 triples):

1. **Large Language Model** (uses) - LLMs serve as the core "brain" for autonomous agents
2. **Autonomous Agent** (proposes) - New LLM-powered agents as patients, nurses, and doctors
3. **Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare** (proposes) - Novel application to medical simulation
4. **Automated Planning and Scheduling** (uses) - Doctor agents plan treatment steps
5. **Reflection (Artificial Intelligence)** (uses) - Agents reason about medical decisions
6. **Natural Language Generation** (uses) - Communication of medical information
7. **Intelligent Agent** (proposes) - Agents perceive environments and act autonomously
8. **Machine Learning** (uses) - Agent performance improvement through experience
9. **Neuroevolution** (proposes) - Evolution of doctor agents without manual labeling
10. **Multi-Agent System** (proposes) - Hospital simulation with multiple interacting agents

**Validation**: All 10 triples passed validation with correct Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relationships properly documented.

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
